ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It's a simple class and it knows what it is. If you just want to go at night and learn the very basics of accounting and finance, it's perfect.
Good content but too many materials to cover within a short span of time (6 weeks).
Q12: The course is very valuable especially for students who has considerations for Renewable Project Finance Course or Forest Finance as it equips one with the basic concepts of finance.

This class was the worst class I have ever taken at FES. It went far too quickly, the TA's were NOT helpful and the instructor was one of the least engaging educators I have ever experienced. The homework assignments made no sense and trying to seek out help from the TA's was next to impossible. They changed their offie hours every week and then when you would go see them they would say "well she explained this in the lecture." The professor didn't seem to be involved in the grading process and didn't seem to understand that ALOT of people were very confused.

This course is way too much work for a single credit, and the two hour lectures are not conducive to effective teaching/learning. Given the apparent interests of most of the students in the class (which fall more on the corporate / management side) and timing needs, iit should be offered as 1.5 credits for an hour and twenty minutes every other day (like a regular class), and fall neatly into the business school's quarter schedule, so that we can balance it out with a second class at SOM.
The course content is very important to my field; however, I am not walking away with a greater understanding of the material. If anything, I am more confused.

The course provided a good foundation in understanding financial vocabulary. It was hard to get passionate about the topic, but it got the job done and provided some complementary information to other courses I was taking.

The class was very fast-paced and the Professor sped through the concepts, so it is hard to retain much information from the class. However, Professor Burke did a great job of preparing the lectures, reading notes etc. so students had access to helpful material. I think the timing of the class was challenging since it was scheduled in the second half of the semester, which is a busy time of the year and it was hard to make the most of the class.

Question 12: This class is so crucial for students without a finance or quantitative background that it needs to be taught by a good professor. Perhaps the guy that teaches renewable energy project finance.

The lecturer is efficient in delivering the materials. I appreciate how she took the time to learn all our names considering how short but big the class is. The TA's were helpful and easily available.

As previous student reviews noted, this course is *way* to fast paced and covers way too much material in too little time. Maureen is good at explaining financial concepts and I think the course would be useful for students without a financial background who then want to take a more advanced course. But for those really looking for financial notions for environmental practitioners I am not sure all the material cover is appropriate.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: General principles of financial/accounting mechanisms are crucial to learn and understand.
Maureen is a good lecturer, and the problem sets were just the right amount of challenging based on lectures.
Assignments
The course is well structured and is easy to follow. The concepts are quite interesting and essential in decision making. The lecturer is engaging and has relevant examples to illustrate the points.
the course is really helpful and the pace of the lecture is well designed
The fact that we used one case (The Good Fish) throughout the entire course was helpful.
Very useful and practical materials.
Explanation of different financial metrics distilled in a clear fashion. The sheet with the different equations/conversions was especially useful.
It's exactly what I was expecting and hoping for.
The in class assignments and problem sets
Homework

Great basic financial framework for people new to the subject and a perfect refresher for people like me who's financial skills are a bit rusty. I found the lecturer's method to be effective: repetition, use of same case, homework

It gave me a good introduction, albeit a too fast paced one, to finance. The material Maureen gives is very useful, but to really learn I will have to go back to it slowly at my own pace to digest the material.
A good introduction to finance and accounting.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Update the slides, dont try and get into the nitty gritty details when the overall topic isnt understood. some people have never learned these things before and this should teach the basics, not abstract pieces.
Pace, make it at least a half-semester.

Pace should be slower/ should be turned into a full semester(3 credit) course. If kept for 1 credit, it will be more useful if it started earlier in the semester instead of in the middle of the semester.
There is a lot to be covered in a little time.

This should really be a semester long course or the amount of content covered needs to be reduced. I would also suggest more examples be used in class so students could contextualize the assignments. Also, this course focuses exclusively on how for profit financial modeling and doesn't address non profit organizations at all.
Slow down explanations .. Perhaps cover fewer topics and do a bit of a deeper dive to ensure comprehension of non-finance background students

Pacing. The class goes far too quickly to absorb anything, which leaves students struggling to figure out how to just get the answers to the assignments right rather than actually learning how to answer the questions.

We cover way too much content with no depth of understanding. The professor does not pace class time so that we finish all material in an equally timed pace. We always rush/skip material in the last ten minutes of class.
The course could have benefited from tie-ins to more real-world examples in addition to the Microsoft, Apple, Amazon ones.
To make the most out of this, it needs to be made into a full semester course.
It would be useful to have the class start earlier in the semester and for Professor Burke to slow down in her explanation of the material.
Teaching style. Updated powerpoints. More support on excel for students with little experience on excel

More like a caveat for interested students, you need to apply yourself to fully reap the benefits of the course. It is a short and swift blow. Be ready to spend time to dive into the material out of class.
The pace is way too fast.

I was taking Renewable Energy Project Finance so I had exposure to some finance but still find this class to be too fast. It doesn't help that it's in the second half of the semester when we are so busy with other classes and cannot put much time into this. I'd propose moving this class to the first half of the semester. I would also recommend that the instructor gives students additional resources (textbook, website, online courses, etc., beyond the PDF notes that Maureen gives us) so that we can go and learn more on our own if we need more financial analysis skills.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: There was no discussion/lab section
The TAs were excellent.
N/A.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Ties in very well with renewable energy project finance and financing green technologies. They're all perfect compliments.
I'm taking the SOM core next year and this really helped me just establish some basic language ability around accounting.

As an environmental expert, we are often faced with decision making. Some of these decisions are financial and requires financial capabilities. This course thus provides the basic concepts that are needful to undertake an investment or to understand the operations of an organization in the case of managers.

So key. Trying to switch to more business and the environment focused. This class was to be my introduction to that. However, mostly other students taught me the material because it wasn't well covered in class.

Fits well into my corporate sustainability focus. It also complements other courses I took relevant to the subject (e.g Metrics, Tools and Indicators of Corporate Responsibility, LCA Practicum, Financing Green Technology). I feel its a good primer and important skill to have for any environmental manager.
I am interested in business and the environment, and finance and accounting are essential to speak the business language and build the business case.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Gain new and useful skills I don't currently have
To get an overview of accounting and finance.

I took Renewable Energy Project Finance Course and realized there were some concepts that were totally new to me but were quickly glazed over and I felt I needed to understand them. Additionally, I have a growing interesting project finance and this was a good place to start.
I think basic financial knowledge should be necessary for a master

I was hoping to gain an understanding of basic financial concepts that I could apply to the non profit and government sector. I had no financial background coming into this course. Overall, this course did not meet my needs and the only people who seemed to thrive were those who had some financial background.
To learn the basics of finance / accounting
To gain more familiarity with financial concepts in order to pursue additional courses on project finance and corporate finance in the future.
To gain a primer understanding of finance.
To understand financial concepts that are important to any manager, in the private or public sector.

Because I am trying to focus more on business and the environment now that Trump has been elected. I believe because of this administration much of the meaningful environmental work will be in the private sector. Understanding of financial concepts will be key for communicating with this sector.
I needed a refresher on financial concepts.
To gain a basis in financial concepts.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Definitely.
Very much. I can go on Yahoo finance and read an income statement now, that feels pretty powerful.

While we did not dive deeply into all the areas, as an introductory course it definitely met my expectation. There were also additional resources provided for further reading which were quite helpful.
yes
No- not at all.
No because of the pacing. Yes, in theory, if it were slower.
Yes. It provided sufficient foundation for financial vocabulary and concepts.
Absolutely

Somewhat. It is hard to know what was retained since the class went by so fast. I plan to review the reading notes and lectures and I think having a take home exam at the end would force students to review all the material and perhaps would have led to more retention of the concepts.
Somewhat.

Yes, for me personally it was what I needed to refresh my practical knowledge of financial concepts. Some of the others struggled more as it was completely new, but I think at the very least the course offers basic financial literacy or language that is necessary for any environmental manager.

yes. I did not come in with high expectations as I knew that based on the previous student reviews and my heavy workload with other classes that I would not be able to get much out of the class, in part because of my schedule, but the fact that it was way too fast paced also contributed to me at times feeling a bit lost.

Yes, given I was warned that the class goes really fast and it's impossible to teach finance/accounting in a one-credit class. I got some exposure but feel that I still need another course to really understand the foundation of finance & accounting.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: N/A
Working in groups was essential since the problem sets were somewhat challenging.
Group work was elective. One could do homework assignments solo or in a group. There's no way I could have done the homework without other students support.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you dont know any financial concepts what so ever, you will struggle. The teaching is not well formatted and understanding everything is almost impossible. Grading the homework out of 3 points means that if you miss 1 point on a homework your grade goes down 7% total. miss 1 point on 3 different homeworks and you are already at a C. not a good way to learn
There is absolutely no reason not to take this class. It's a light load and the topics are crucial to life out in the real world. Everyone should do it.
It is a means to an end. The course exposes one to several new concepts and there is need to go further beyond the class if one has the interest. There is much one can do beyond the class itself.
it's a good course for a student without any financial and economic training
I would suggest students take a full semester course that reviews the concepts in a clear and more manageable way.
I'd recommend for a broad overview of financial concepts - a good starting point to further explore additional coursework that might go more in-depth.
I do not recommend this course in the way it was taught this semester. The material is very important, but the instruction is difficult to follow.

It offers an effective way of learning basic financial concepts. You'll have to take other courses for more detailed/in depth examples and explanations. For instance, taking Renewable Energy Project Finance concurrently will provide you more experience with calculating NPV and IRR in a practical sense, while this course offers more explanation of using the tools in broader assessment of financial metrics.
I recommend it but make sure to read the reading notes and review the lectures.

Go to the TA office hours. Make sure you make friends in the class who can help you with the homework. Don't get down on yourself if you're confused and don't get it. Most of the other students I watched didn't either.

As mentioned before, you need to apply yourself to fully reap the benefits of the course. It is a short and swift blow. Spend a little time outside class to go through the concepts yourself. Work through problem sets yourself first before asking TA's or classmates to help. Take this course, it's an important primer. Environmental managers need to be more financially savvy!
Realize that you might not learn much, but that you will then have the material to go back to.

For students who want a strong foundation in finance and accounting, which believe me is important if you are interested in anything to do with the business world, I'd recommend taking the full class in the fall at SOM
